Chapter 4: Motion in 2D & 3D

Projectiles, Circles, and Complex Motion

Explore the fascinating world of motion in multiple dimensions, from projectile trajectories to planetary orbits.

🌟 Why Study Motion in Multiple Dimensions?

🚀 Real-World Motion is Rarely 1D

  • How do basketball players calculate the perfect shot angle?
  • Why do satellites orbit Earth instead of flying off into space?
  • How do pilots navigate aircraft through complex flight paths?
  • What makes a roller coaster loop-the-loop safely?

Most real-world motion occurs in two or three dimensions. This chapter builds on your understanding of forces and Newton's laws to analyze complex motions that combine multiple types of acceleration and force.

🎯 Practical Applications

  • Sports: Projectile motion in baseball, basketball, and soccer
  • Engineering: Satellite trajectories and space missions
  • Transportation: Aircraft navigation and vehicle dynamics
  • Entertainment: Roller coaster design and video game physics
  • Safety: Crash dynamics and protective equipment design

4.1 📐 Vector Analysis in 2D & 3D

💡 Think of Vectors Like GPS Directions: Just as GPS tells you both how far to go AND which direction, vectors tell us both magnitude (how much) and direction (which way).

Vector Components

Any vector in 2D or 3D can be broken down into perpendicular components. This is like describing a diagonal move on a chess board as a combination of horizontal and vertical moves.

2D Vector Components:
Aₓ = A cos θ
Aᵧ = A sin θ
|A| = √(Aₓ² + Aᵧ²)

Vector Addition

🔍 Component Method for Vector Addition:

  1. Break each vector into x, y (and z) components
  2. Add all x-components: Rₓ = A₁ₓ + A₂ₓ + A₃ₓ + ...
  3. Add all y-components: Rᵧ = A₁ᵧ + A₂ᵧ + A₃ᵧ + ...
  4. Find magnitude: |R| = √(Rₓ² + Rᵧ²)
  5. Find direction: θ = tan⁻¹(Rᵧ/Rₓ)

📝 Example: Displacement Vectors

Problem: A hiker walks 5 km north, then 3 km east, then 2 km at 45° northeast. Find the total displacement.

Solution:

Vector 1: (0, 5) km

Vector 2: (3, 0) km

Vector 3: (2cos45°, 2sin45°) = (1.41, 1.41) km

Total: (4.41, 6.41) km

Magnitude: √(4.41² + 6.41²) = 7.8 km

Direction: 55.5° north of east

🤔 Conceptual Questions

Question 1: Can two vectors of different magnitudes add up to give a zero resultant? If so, under what conditions?
Show Answer

No, two vectors of different magnitudes cannot add up to zero. For two vectors to cancel out (give zero resultant), they must have equal magnitudes and opposite directions. This is because |A + B| = 0 only when A = -B, which requires |A| = |B|.

Question 2: A pilot wants to fly due north but there's a crosswind from the west. Should the pilot aim the plane due north, northeast, or northwest? Explain.
Show Answer

The pilot should aim northwest. The plane's velocity relative to air plus the wind velocity must equal the desired ground velocity (due north). Since wind pushes east, the plane must aim west of north to compensate, resulting in a northwest heading.

🧮 Numerical Problems

Problem 1: Three forces act on an object: 10 N at 0°, 15 N at 90°, and 20 N at 180°. Find the net force.
Show Solution

Components:

F₁ₓ = 10 N, F₁ᵧ = 0 N

F₂ₓ = 0 N, F₂ᵧ = 15 N

F₃ₓ = -20 N, F₃ᵧ = 0 N

Net components: Fₓ = -10 N, Fᵧ = 15 N

Magnitude: |F| = √(10² + 15²) = 18.0 N

Direction: 123.7° (or 56.3° above negative x-axis)

4.2 🏀 Projectile Motion

💡 Key Insight: Projectile motion is just two 1D motions happening simultaneously - constant horizontal velocity and uniformly accelerated vertical motion under gravity.

Principles of Projectile Motion

🔑 Fundamental Assumptions:

  • No air resistance: Only gravity acts on the projectile
  • Horizontal independence: vₓ remains constant throughout flight
  • Vertical acceleration: aᵧ = -g = -9.8 m/s² (downward)
  • Initial conditions: v₀ₓ = v₀ cos θ, v₀ᵧ = v₀ sin θ
Projectile Motion Equations:
x = v₀ₓt = v₀ cos θ · t
y = v₀ᵧt - ½gt² = v₀ sin θ · t - ½gt²
vₓ = v₀ cos θ
vᵧ = v₀ sin θ - gt

Key Parameters

📊 Important Projectile Characteristics:

Time of Flight: T = (2v₀ sin θ)/g

Maximum Height: H = (v₀² sin² θ)/(2g)

Range: R = (v₀² sin 2θ)/g

Maximum Range: Occurs at θ = 45°

🤔 Conceptual Questions

Question 1: A ball is thrown horizontally from a cliff. Another identical ball is dropped from the same height at the same time. Which hits the ground first?
Show Answer

Both balls hit the ground at the same time. The horizontal velocity of the thrown ball doesn't affect its vertical motion. Both experience the same vertical acceleration (gravity) and fall the same vertical distance, so they take the same time to fall.

Question 2: At what angle should you launch a projectile to achieve maximum range on level ground?
Show Answer

45° gives maximum range on level ground. This is because range R = (v₀² sin 2θ)/g, and sin 2θ is maximum when 2θ = 90°, so θ = 45°. At this angle, the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity are equal.

🧮 Numerical Problems

Problem 1: A ball is kicked at 20 m/s at an angle of 30° above horizontal. Find: (a) time of flight, (b) maximum height, (c) range.
Show Solution

Given: v₀ = 20 m/s, θ = 30°, g = 9.8 m/s²

(a) Time of flight: T = (2v₀ sin θ)/g = (2 × 20 × sin 30°)/9.8 = 2.04 s

(b) Maximum height: H = (v₀² sin² θ)/(2g) = (400 × 0.25)/(19.6) = 5.1 m

(c) Range: R = (v₀² sin 2θ)/g = (400 × sin 60°)/9.8 = 35.3 m

4.3 🌀 Circular Motion

💡 Remember: Even at constant speed, circular motion involves acceleration because the direction of velocity is constantly changing!

Centripetal Acceleration

Objects moving in circles experience centripetal acceleration directed toward the center of the circular path.

Centripetal Acceleration:
aᶜ = v²/r = ω²r
ω = v/r = 2π/T
where ω is angular velocity and T is period

Centripetal Force

🔑 Newton's Second Law for Circular Motion:

Fᶜ = maᶜ = mv²/r

The centripetal force is not a new type of force - it's the net inward force provided by gravity, tension, friction, normal force, etc.

📝 Example: Car on a Banked Curve

Problem: A car travels around a banked curve. Analyze the forces that provide centripetal acceleration.

Forces involved:

  • Weight (mg) - vertically downward
  • Normal force (N) - perpendicular to road surface
  • Friction (f) - parallel to road surface

The horizontal components of these forces combine to provide the required centripetal force.

🤔 Conceptual Questions

Question 1: A ball attached to a string is whirled in a horizontal circle. If the string breaks, which direction will the ball fly?
Show Answer

The ball will fly off tangent to the circle at the point where the string breaks. This follows Newton's First Law - without the centripetal force from the string, the ball continues in a straight line in whatever direction it was moving at that instant.

🧮 Numerical Problems

Problem 1: A 1200 kg car travels at 15 m/s around a circular track of radius 50 m. What centripetal force is required?
Show Solution

Given: m = 1200 kg, v = 15 m/s, r = 50 m

Centripetal force: Fᶜ = mv²/r = (1200 × 15²)/50 = 5400 N

This force must be provided by friction between tires and road.

4.4 🚂 Relative Motion

💡 Key Concept: Motion is always relative to a reference frame. A passenger on a moving train has different velocities relative to the train vs. relative to the ground.

Reference Frames

The description of motion depends on the chosen reference frame. Relative velocity relates the motion observed in different frames.

Relative Velocity:
v⃗ₐ/ᶜ = v⃗ₐ/ᵦ + v⃗ᵦ/ᶜ
where A/C means "A relative to C"

📝 Example: River Crossing

Problem: A boat can travel at 5 m/s in still water. The river flows at 3 m/s eastward. If the boat aims directly north, what is its velocity relative to the shore?

Solution:

Boat velocity relative to water: 5 m/s north

Water velocity relative to shore: 3 m/s east

Resultant velocity: √(5² + 3²) = 5.83 m/s at 30.96° east of north

🤔 Conceptual Questions

Question 1: Two cars approach each other, each traveling at 30 m/s. What is their relative velocity?
Show Answer

Their relative velocity is 60 m/s. From the perspective of one car, the other car approaches at 30 m/s (its own speed) + 30 m/s (the other car's speed) = 60 m/s.

🧮 Numerical Problems

Problem 1: A pilot wants to fly from city A to city B, which is 200 km due north. The plane can fly at 150 km/h in still air, but there's a 50 km/h wind from the west. In what direction should the pilot head, and how long will the trip take?
Show Solution

Given: Plane speed = 150 km/h, Wind = 50 km/h from west, Distance = 200 km north

Heading: θ = sin⁻¹(50/150) = 19.47° west of north

Ground speed north: vₙ = √(150² - 50²) = 141.4 km/h

Flight time: t = 200/141.4 = 1.41 hours
